Award.AwardTitle: DeceptiCon: A conference on the study of deception, trust and technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Deception and trust are deeply integrated into almost all facets of life, and the current attention on truth and trust on the Internet and in new media highlights the importance of these topics to our society. It is vital that interdisciplinary groups work together to identify and understand (a) means of deception (b) the potential consequences (c) how we may counteract deception and (d) how to build and restore trust in social and technical systems. As the only conference in the world dedicated to the study of deception and trust, DeceptiCon 2017 offers a collaborative space where professionals and academics can converge to discuss and debate the state of the art in their respective fields related to truth, trust and technology.

This award supports Decepticon 2017 to be held at Stanford University in August 2017. The program covers a variety of topics, such as cues to deceit, methods of deception detection and the use of technology to detect deception,theoretical positions on deception and its detection, and research on methods and factors that promote trust and improve credibility analysis to support a trustworthy cyberspace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals of Decepticon 2017 Conference are (1) promoting research and practices in deception detections (2) promoting collaborations among diverse disciplines. 

More than 130 people attended Decepticon 2017. Participants were from multiple disciplines, including Psychology, Communication, Computer Science, and Criminal Justice. The conference had four keynote speeches, two panels and 20 conference presentations and 35 poster presentations. The conference program covered all key aspects of deception research and practices, such as deception theories, deception and technology, deception detection, training and implementation, and cross-cultural deception. 

Our conference exit survey and evaluation indicated that participants truly enjoyed the conference. They liked that the speakers, presentations and panels were in-depth, interesting and high-quality. They also appreciated the representations from a variety of fields and backgrounds. Here are some of the comments participants put in their survey: (1) “High-quality research, new findings within our area! Some interesting talks, insights from practitioners.” (2) “WIDE VARIETY of topics covered! Key researchers of deception detection present. Networking opportunities were fantastic. Food perfect! Environment outstanding.” (3) “The set up was very good, good IT support! Keynotes so far have been excellent. Presentations involving technology, social media, etc. have been extremely informative. This is something that conferences do better - introduce brand new, up to the minute material. Food and the location was great, excellent! And everyone was very friendly. Good balance of men and women presenting.” (4) “Multidisciplinary approach. Great presenter among which leaders in the field. Good balance between different session (variety, breaks). Great catering and casual atmosphere. To all team: Thank you!”
